description:
Anaerococcus porci is a species of anaerobic, Gram-positive, coccoid-shaped bacterium that was isolated from the fecal samples of pigs. It belongs to the genus Anaerococcus, which are members of the phylum Firmicutes and the family Peptoniphilaceae.

Anaerococcus porci is a fastidious, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium. It grows optimally under anaerobic conditions and requires complex growth media for cultivation. Biochemical analysis has shown that Anaerococcus porci is able to ferment various carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and lactose, to produce organic acids as the end products of its metabolism.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has revealed that Anaerococcus porci is closely related to other Anaerococcus species, such as Anaerococcus prevotii and Anaerococcus hydrogenalis, which have also been isolated from human and animal gut microbiomes.

The ecological role and potential clinical significance of Anaerococcus porci in the porcine gut microbiome are still under investigation, as further research is needed to understand its interactions with the host and its potential involvement in health or disease states.
